channel.title: Is this PC build good value?
channel.description:
http://uk.pcpartpicker.com/p/7NZG6h
Brother is looking to build a PC and he's come up with this. What do you guys think?

item.description:
@RUNE-PK wrote:

For 340$ I’d say thats okay. My brother bough his pc from www.cyberpowerpc.com and paid 1200$ and what your brother has picked is better then his and allot cheaper

item.title: Is this PC build good value?
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

Those are some really old parts. With £500 he can get better newer parts. What does he plan to do on that PC?

Read full topic
item.source: Is this PC build good value?

item.title: Is this PC build good value?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Some people still prefer to have discs instead of virtual downloaded games, or actually buy movie bluerays/dvds. They aren’t really being outmoded yet, except in the more techie market (people that do everything virtually). I don’t have an optical drive in my PC and suffered for it when I was trying to reinstall my operating system, because it was on a disk from my manufacturer and had the key in the DVD. Had to call them for the key to use USB installation because of that. Personally I hate external optical drives, but they have their uses depending on your situation. If you dont need to use it on multiple systems, stick with an internal one.

Read full topic
item.source: Is this PC build good value?

item.title: Is this PC build good value?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Justin Bieber:

Personally I would get an internal optical drive. They’re not exactly more expensive than the external ones, and at least u don’t have to fanny around with cables and having shit on your desk.

But with an external one you can use it on all PCs, laptops without optical drives, even let a friend borrow it if you want, just great for portability.

Besides, when’s the last time you used a CD/DVD? I’ve only needed to use it about three times in the three years I’ve had my build… can’t deny that DVDs are becoming like floppy disks, redundant.

Read full topic
item.source: Is this PC build good value?

item.title: Is this PC build good value?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Justin Bieber:

That price is definitely good for an i7

It’s really really old - over 5 years to be precise.

And on that note, buy a new i5 or i7 with an appropriate accompanying motherboard.

Read full topic

item.title: Is this PC build good value?
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

http://pcpartpicker.com/guide/23yp99/600-budget-beast

I’m a big fan of AMD and hate how expensive Intel is. Supposedly the price is actually good for performance for Intel i7 CPUs, but I highly doubt it. Any way, the guide I built above is made great for gaming and high-load applications. If you’re really on a low budget, then I’d suggest that, but I guess it’s always best to learn more from building your own.

Read full topic
item.source: Is this PC build good value?

item.title: Is this PC build good value?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

CPU is way overpowered in comparison to the GPU, I’d get at least a GTX 760 or 9 series equivalent (950).

To answer the question in the OP, yes, though if you wanted to save a bit of cash I don’t think the cooler master CPU cooler is really necessary, the stock cooler is perfectly fine unless you’re overclocking, which you probably won’t need to. And why bother with internal DVD drives? Buy a USB external one for £10 and never have to buy an internal one ever again.

Read full topic
item.source: Is this PC build good value?

item.title: Is this PC build good value?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Soulcist, post:2, topic:550362”]Might be a dumb question but I’m interested in knowing, but what’s the difference between the two?

http://puu.sh/gnMDf/9edb627e8b.png

Is the memory for the RAM and the other one I only assume is what you would see when you pull up your C drive information? Why would you want to have more memory for the RAM (e.g. I have 4 GB on this GB, 3.89 of it is usable)?

Sorry to derail your topic but… I’m a little curios. :L[/quote]
The memory is the RAM.

The usable memory is the installed ram - hardware reserved.
So basically, if your computer takes .5mb RAM to run, then it will take .5mb off the usable.

Read full topic
item.source: Is this PC build good value?

item.title: Is this PC build good value?
item.dc:creator: @naseem142 naseem142
item.description:
@naseem142 wrote:

[quote=“Soulcist, post:2, topic:550362”]Might be a dumb question but I’m interested in knowing, but what’s the difference between the two?

http://puu.sh/gnMDf/9edb627e8b.png

Is the memory for the RAM and the other one I only assume is what you would see when you pull up your C drive information? Why would you want to have more memory for the RAM (e.g. I have 4 GB on this GB, 3.89 of it is usable)?

Sorry to derail your topic but… I’m a little curios. :L[/quote]

That’s a hard drive and the other one is a RAM, they have nothing to do with each other?

Everything looks good , but i’d change the video card to a MSI,sapphire R7 260X 2gb. If your bro has a few more bucks to spare. If not, he could lower the PSU to a cheaper 520W modular one and make up for it in on the video card.

Read full topic
